page.title: 14Birds
page.content: The moors around Middlezoy make up the best area for breeding wading birds in the south-west of England. The most commonly seen of the waders are lapwings, curlews, redshank and snipe. In summer smaller birds such as yellow wagtails, which have emigrated from Africa, use the moors as their breeding ground attracted by the undrained grazing meadows. Whinchats and sedge warblers nest among the taller vegetation alongside the rhynes (as the ditches are known in this area). The pollarded willows which grow along many of the rhynes provide nesting holes for birds such as owls, tree sparrows and redstarts. Mallards and mute swans also build nests here. There are other breeding birds in the area, but these are the ones that depend on the unusual landscape.
